text.text: A Guide to Leyton

Leyton is like a little village in the Big Bad Smoke. People are friendly, products are locally sourced and independent businesses just generally seem to support each other. We half expected them to break into the opening song from Beauty and the Beast at one point. 

All joking aside, it's a little rough and ready but still worth rolling into to see what a community really feels like, drink coffee in a bookshop that cares, eat food that knows where it's from and try your hand at the legendary music bingo.
Best for... a strong cup o' joe

tip.text:
Perky Blenders sell their beans to venues all about East London, but this is their headquarters. Beans are sourced from South America and Africa and roast right here, in the backroom. It's a small room, for small batch coffee - makes sense right?

Coffees are on point, teas are soothing, and chai lattes are rife, but what makes Perky different from your standard artisan coffee shop is the focus on drinks rather than food. Sure you can grab a muffin if it's calling your name, or pop in for Greek food on Sundays, but what you really want is an espresso martini or old fashioned made with their in-house coffee bitters. It's a small, unassuming spot, it may even look a little unfinished, but sometimes all you need is a reliable perch to drink local beer that isn't a pub - and Perky has just that.

text.text:
Start your day right at Perky's with a strong cup of joe. They sell their in-house blend to a great many of the self respecting coffee houses of East London, so you know it's good stuff. 

It's sourced from South America and Africa and roasted right here in the backroom. Sure you can stock up on lattes and flat whites but we like ours in an espresso martini. Cause we cray.
Best for... warming Scottish grub

tip.text:
Owner Carol grew up north of the wall but has decided to bring a little taste of Scotland down to East London. Starting with a street food stall, she's been honing her recipe for haggis toasties. Ask any Scott worth their Irn Bru and they'll tell you all about the stuff. It's basically minced sheep's pluck (that's organs chaps) chopped up with onion, oatmeal, suet & spices. It used to be served in the sheep's stomach (hence why some people get a little edgy) but these days it's just pipped into your standard sausage sacking.

Deeney's have taken this glorious edible and shoved it in a toastie with cheddar, caramelised onion and rocket. Try one and you'll get an idea of what it's all about, how tasty it can be, and how the good people of Scotland survive the winter. There's even a veggie version that is just as good, if not better. Now settled in this cosy cafe, Carol's Scottish crusade continues with small baked goods, brownies, fudge, and tidy deep fried mars bars. Just don't tell your doctor.

text.text:
Deeney's founder, Carol, grew up north of the wall and brings us her twist on a Scottish classic, haggis. Ask any Scott worth their Irn Bru and they'll tell you it's basically minced sheep's pluck (that's organs, chaps) chopped up with onion, oatmeal, suet and spices. 

Carol's shoved her haggis concoction in a toastie with cheddar, caramelised onion and rocket. Try one and you'll get an idea of how the good people of Scotland survive the winter.
Best for... a seasonal feast

tip.text:
Marmelo knows exactly how to tease its punters with to-die-for homemade grub. Owner and head chef Natalie was the first of many businesses to settle in this village-like corner of Leyton. She saw potential, and she was right.

Serving indulgent brunches, epic Sunday roasts, and a veg-heavy evening menu, there's always an excuse to drop in. Wine is natural, ingredients seasonal, menus change weekly, and all meat, fish, and veg is sustainably sourced. It's hard to say what you'll have, but we sat at the counter and watched the chef create wild mushroom and truffle arancini; smoked beetroot with greek yoghurt and pistachio dukkah (Middle Eastern spices); and the most succulent beef shin stew. It's all made fresh, in front of your eyes, and tastes like heaven.

Marmelo's aesthetic is a dreamy kind of farmhouse chic. It's all white walls, wooden tables, simple lighting, and quality ceramics. We were soothed from start to finish.

text.text:
Owner and head chef Natalie was one of the first to settle in this village-like corner of Leyton. She saw a potential market for her indulgent brunches, epic Sunday roasts, and sustainable veg-heavy menu... She was right.

We plonked ourselves at the counter and watched the chef create wild mushroom and truffle arancini; and the most succulent beef shin stew. It's all made fresh, in front of your eyes, and tastes like heaven.
Best for... one of a kind trinkets

tip.text:
It's a tale of two artists: illustrator Tiff Howick and jewellery designer Lucie Ellen. They got sick of lonely studio time, they wanted a shop, they were friends, and now they've a tidy racket. Venner acts as a shop, gallery, and workshop space for them and other local artists and craftspeople. Soak up the artisan vibes whilst gazing at jewellery, bags, ceramics, prints, woodcuts, and other finds.

Everything is ethical, environmentally friendly, and sustainably sourced - which is reflected in the price. But if you are in the business of supporting small businesses and local artists, then great. You'll likely leave with something beautiful and original, something with a story.

text.text:
It's a tale of two artists: illustrator Tiff and jewellery designer Lucie. They got sick of lonely studio time and wanted a local shop championing local goods - so they thought up Venner. 

Everything is ethical, environmentally friendly, and sustainably sourced from jewellery, bags and ceramics, to prints and woodcuts. If you are in the business of supporting independent shops and local artists, then you'll love it. You'll likely leave with something beautiful and original.
Best for... cosying up with a book

tip.text:
Phlox Books is a haven for the bibliophiles of East London, providing new and second-hand books alongside seriously homely vibes. Enter the shop and be met with a tidy selection of reading material set against wooden panelling and rustic furnishings. After working in bookshops all her life, Aim√©e wanted to make hers less intimidating. She wants you to pop in, feel comfortable, ask questions, have a read, and maybe even a drink.

The counter serving Allpress coffee, wine, and craft beer makes it even easier to spend an afternoon lazing around in this charming nook of a shop. If you're lucky, you might even steal a cuddle with resident French bulldog Huxley.

Check their Insta for info on events, talks, and collaborations with Francis Road's other resident businesses.

text.text:
After working in bookshops all her life, Aim√©e needed to make hers less intimidating. She wants you to pop in to Phlox, feel at home, ask questions and have a good old rummage.

The counter serving Allpress coffee, wine, and craft beer makes it even easier to linger in this charming nook of a shop. If you're lucky, you might even steal a cuddle with resident French bulldog Huxley.
Best for... a glass of something fine

tip.text:
Whatever a yardarm is, you're not meant to drink 'til the sun is over it. When the sun is indeed over it, then it must be five o'clock somewhere. Right? This particular Yardarm is basically a glorified (and mighty stylish) 'food and wine', run by Eliza (the sommelier) and her hubby.

Up front you've got your wine, beer, cheese, condiments and the like - all to be taken away to your very own home. And in the back? Well you can pull up a pew and sip on a little something by the glass, grab a coffee, or get stuck into a pastel de nata. There's even a fully functional garden (it has chairs). If all that has tickled your fancy then try one of their beer and wine tastings from ¬£25 for 6 tasters and nibbles. Not bad for an offie, eh kids?

text.text:
Yardarm is basically a glorified (and mighty stylish) 'food and wine', run by Eliza (the sommelier) and her hubby. And as the old saying goes, you're not supposed to drink till the sun is over it. (The yardarm.)

Up front you've got your wine, beer, cheese, condiments and the like. And round back you can pull up a pew and sip on a little something by the glass. Not bad for an offie, really.
Best for... real ale and quirks

tip.text:
This pub has been both a town hall and a technical college, hence the name. The facade is sexy as hell and the rooms inside (there are lots) are just as fit. We ooh'd and aah'd at high ceilings, marbled mosaic floors, higgledy-piggledy mirrors, paintings, taxidermy, and shelves filled with second hand books and bric-a-brac. The result is comforting and disconcerting at the same time - kinda like going through your gran's stuff behind her back.

Leyton Technical takes their food pretty seriously with a menu fancier than you're used to seeing in a boozer. Classics like sausage and mash are poshed up, and dishes like chicken schnitzel come with white bean, bacon, and kale stew. They do a interesting selection of real ales (we tried one that promised notes of tea and biscuits), live music, pub quizzes, and comedy nights - it's a box ticker for sure.

text.text:
We ooh'd and aah'd at Leyton Technical's high ceilings, marbled mosaic floors, higgledy-piggledy mirrors, paintings and taxidermy - for far too long. (So long that our camera ran out of battery.) The result of all their bric-a-brac is comforting and disconcerting at the same time - a lot like going through your gran's stuff behind her back. 

We popped in for a pint of ale (one that promised notes of tea and biscuits) and sipped it real slow.
Best for... a spot of karaoke

tip.text:
The Leyton Star must have huge sleeves considering all the tricks that are up there. All seems pretty standard at first glance with dark blue walls, the odd disco ball, and an open fire, but a quick rummage reveals a big ol' beer garden; a games room with darts, table football, and a retro arcade machine; and not one but two hireable karaoke rooms. Why did they buy huge gold trees from Paloma Faith's world tour for their beer garden? Well that's just another one of life's great questions.

Go quizzing on Tuesdays, cut shapes on Fridays, or just grab yourself some killer grub by 'We Serve Humans' - think meaty burgers, veggie burgers, buffalo wings, and Sunday roasts that comfort the heck outa your hangover. It's like pub grub, but better, ok?

text.text:
The Leyton Star must have huge sleeves considering all the tricks that are up there. All seems pretty standard at first glance but a quick rummage reveals a big ol' beer garden, darts, table football, a retro arcade machine and not one but two hireable karaoke rooms. 

You want more? Try quiz Tuesdays, DJ Fridays and some incredibly tasty roast Sundays. Also known as Sunday roasts.
Best for... finding friendly faces

tip.text:
The Northcote Arms is one of the friendliest pubs we've come across in a while. By day it's filled with locals having a good old natter, then in the evenings things perk up substantially. The whole thing is run by the lovely Tuesday, who's put together a killer events schedule - live music, drag nights, music bingo, life drawing, whisky tastings, comedy nights, old vinyl showcases, and more. There's wood-fired pizza to be had, kitchen residencies, and even a bottomless bloody mary option on a Sunday - ideal.

Particularly charming in the summertime is the walled garden decked out with fairy lights, where acoustic bands have been known to raise the roof - or lack thereof.

text.text:
The Northcote Arms is one of the friendliest pubs we've come across. By day it's filled with locals having a good old natter, then in the evenings things perk up substantially. 

It's run by the lovely Tuesday, who's put together a killer events schedule. Our picks were the music bingo, drag nights and live acoustic performances in the garden. Pair that with wood-fired pizza and you've got yourself a dream pub.
And here's our picks for Leytonstone...
